xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: Funding for this study comes from the Chulalongkorn Economics Research Center. We would like to thank the Bangkok-based charity and administrators at participating schools for their cooperation in allowing us access to their administrative records for this study. We would like to acknowledge the following students for their research assistance: Tansaya Kunaratskul, Sorasit Petchdee, Pornchanok Phairot, Phattranun Pruetpattra, Woraphong Sawatrukkiat, Chanipa Tringkajee, Chaniporn Tringkajee and Virapol Wet-Urai. Finally, we would like to thank the associate editor and two anonymous referees for their useful comments and suggestions. We are responsible for all errors and omissions.

organization.$: University of the Thai Chamber of Commerce

head.citation-title: Transfer payments and upper secondary school outcomes: The case of low-income female students in Thailand
head.abstracts: © 2015 World Scientific Publishing Company.This study assesses the impact of cash transfers to low-income female Thai students on improving upper secondary school outcomes, as measured by grade point average (GPA) and transition to tertiary education. Utilizing official records from a charity organization providing substantial cash transfers to secondary students and student records from participating schools, we find the transfers have no effect on improving recipients' GPAs compared to non-recipients. However, the scholarship recipients are 22% more likely to transition to university education than non-recipients and the presence of scholarship recipients in the classroom increases the likelihood of female non-recipients to attend university.
